Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery closed vessel, probably the lid of a Nikosthenic pyxis; interior reserved; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of lower part of two figures to left (woman wearing chiton in added red and black himation, both with decorated borders; added white on feet; and one leg of man); between them, painted inscription; below, four dilute bands above the tendrils of a lotus-bud chain.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 329, no. B374)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0823) (Phase 1)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 97, pl. III, no. 25)
Lyon 2009 / Nikosthenic Pyxides between Etruria and Greece (p. 176, no. 19)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
